title: 5.16 Diffusion limited aggregation (DLA)
text:
This is an implementation of an on-lattice (i.e. grid-based) diffusion-limited aggregation process. See
Witten TA and LM Sander. 1981. Diffusion-limited aggregation, a kinetic critical phenomenon. Physical Review Letters 47 1400–1403.


Typical behaviour of this model is seen in the video below.

title: 5.15 Eden spread on a linear front with long-distance dispersal (LDD)
text:
This model shows how Eden spread along a front is dramatically altered by the occurrence of even relatively rare long-distance jumps. The behaviour of this model should be compared with that of the same model without such jumps.
This model requires the R extension.
crumbs: 5.15 Eden spread on a linear front with long-distance dispersal (LDD)

title: 5.9 The Eden tree
text:
This model is an implementation of an Eden tree growth process as discussed in
Dhar D and R Ramaswamy. 1985. Classical diffusion on Eden trees. Physical Review Letters 54 1346–1349.


Typical behaviour of this model is seen in the video below.

title: 5.8 Inverted Eden process
text:
This model is an implementation of the simple inverse Eden process presented in
Savakis AE and SA Maggelakis. 1997. Models of shrinking clusters with applications to epidermal wound healing. Mathematical and Computer Modelling 25 1–6.


Typical behaviour of this model is seen in the video below.

title: 5.13 Eden epidemic process
text:
This model simulates an Eden epidemic process as described in
Alexandrowicz Z. 1980. Critically branched chains and percolation clusters. Physics Letters A 80 284–286.


Typical behaviour of this model is seen in the video below.

title: 5.6 Invasion percolation drainage basin model
text:
This model is an implementation of the drainage model presented in
Stark CP. 1991. An invasion percolation model of drainage network evolution. Nature 352 423–425.


Typical behaviour of this model is seen in the video below.

title: 5.7 Simple Eden growth model
text:
This model is an implementation of the basic Eden growth process as originally presented in
Eden M. 1961. A two-dimensional growth process, 4th Berkeley Symposium on Mathematical Statistics and Probability, pp. 223–239, University of California Press, Berkeley, CA.


Typical behaviour of this model is seen in the video below.

title: 5.5 Invasion percolation
text:
This model demonstrates invasion percolation in a landscape with randomly assigned resistance values.
The NetLogo code in this model is some of the most complicated in the whole of the model zoo, particularly the variant that identifies ‘traps’, which are the regions shaded in grey (see the video) from which it is clear that the invasion cluster cannot ‘escape’ to the right-hand side of the model space.


Typical behaviour of this model is seen in the video below.

title: 5.21 Stark model of gullying
text:
This model is an approximate implementation of the model described in
Stark CP. 1994. Cluster growth modeling of plateau erosion. Journal of Geophysical Research 99 13957-69.
which combines invasion percolation, diffusion-limited aggregation and Eden growth to simulated gullying erosion at a plateau edge.

title: 5.18 The SIMMAP neutral landscape model
text:
This model implements the SIMMAP process for generation of neutral landscapes as described in
Saura S and J Martinez-Milan. 2000. Landscape pattern simulation with a modified random clusters method. Landscape Ecology 15 661-677.
This model also requires this text file to configure the relative proportions of each class of landscape that it will produce. This file should not be renamed, and should be placed in the same folder as the model file.
The first line of this file indicates the number of different landscape classes required. Subsequent lines indicate for each required class the desired relative proportion of the landscape that it should occupy. If the model’s percolation parameter is set too high, then it may be very difficult for the model to produce landscapes with proportions close to the requested levels.

title: 5.3 Site percolation forest fire model
text:
A simple site-percolation based model of a forest-fire (or any other contagious process).


Typical behaviour of this model is seen in the video below.

title: Pattern, process and scale
text:
This chapter focuses its attention on concepts central to the study of spatial models, pattern and process. A third important concept – scale – is also introduced, and the ways in which patterns and processes may change depending on the spatial and temporal scale at which analysis is conducted are considered. We explore these ideas by considering statistical point processes that produce static point patterns, and also show how such static models can easily transition to dynamic models similar to those considered in the remainder of the book.












2.1 Scaling a pattern



















2.2 Flügge et al.’s spatial memory model



















2.3 Complete spatial randomness for a point pattern



















2.4 The inhomogeneous point process



















2.5 A point process with inhibition



















2.6 Point processes with clustering



















2.7 The double Thomas point process















No matching items

title: 2.2 Flügge et al.’s spatial memory model
text:
This is an implementation of the model described in
Flügge AJ, SC Olhede and D Murrell. 2012. The memory of spatial patterns – changes in local abundance and aggregation in a tropical forest. Ecology 93, 1540-49.
This model also requires this NetLogo source file to run. You should place this file in the same folder as the model .nlogo file.





Typical behaviour of this model is seen in the video below.
crumbs: 2.2 Flügge et al.'s spatial memory model

title: 2.5 A point process with inhibition
text: This model demonstrates a point process with inhibition which prevents two events from being located nearer one another than some specified distances and can produce evenly-spaced or dispersed patterns.

title: 2.6 Point processes with clustering
text: This model demonstrates Thomas and Matern point processes which can be tuned to produce patterns that exhibit distinct clusters of events.

title: 3.14 Spots and stripes: a discrete reaction-diffusion model
text:
This model implements the cellular automaton model described by
Young DA. 1984. A local activator-inhibitor model of vertebrate skin patterns. Mathematical Biosciences 72 51–58.
which is itself a cellular automaton discretisation of Turing’s reaction-diffusion model of morphogenetics.
Turing AM. 1952.. The chemical basis of morphogenesis. Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London. Series B 237 37–72
The reaction-diffusion model is a fundamental process model across many scientific domains.





Typical behaviour of this model is seen in the video below.
crumbs: 3.14 Spots and stripes: a discrete reaction-diffusion model

title: 3.16 Evolutionary spatial prisoners’ dilemma
text:
This model demonstrates how different strategies in a two player game compete with one another in space, when players ‘evolve’ by changing their strategy to match successfully strategies either globally (the non-spatial case) or locally (the spatial case).





Typical behaviour of this model is seen in the video below.

title: 3.13 Centroidal Voronoi tessellation
text:
The Voronoi tessellation is an ‘all at once’ subdivision of a landscape based on proximity to a set of generating points. Many possible iterative processes based on the Voronoi tessellation are possible. This model demonstrates one example, the centroidal Voronoi tessellation where successive generations of generating points are placed at the centroids of the previous generation of Voronoi tiles. See
Du Q, V Faber and M Gunzburger. 1999. Centroidal Voronoi tessellations: applications and algorithms. SIAM Review 41 637–76.





Typical behaviour of this model is seen in the video below.

title: 3.10 The Schelling model of segregation
text:
This model is one possible implementation of Thomas Schelling’s simple model of residential segregation. This implementation shows how changing the criterion for how a household decides that a prospective new location is acceptable or not can change the overall outcome quite dramatically. The original papers on this model are:





Schelling TC. 1969. Models of segregation. American Economic Review 59 488–493.
Schelling TC. 1971. Dynamic models of segregation. Journal of Mathematical Sociology 1 143–186.
Schelling TC. 1978. Micromotives and Macrobehavior. Norton, New York.
It has more recently been argued that the model should be more properly referred to as the Sakoda-Schelling model. See:
Hegselmann R. 2017. Thomas C. Schelling and James M. Sakoda: The intellectual, technical, and social history of a model. Journal of Artificial Societies and Social Simulation 20(3).
Sakoda JM. 1971. The checkerboard model of social interaction. Journal of Mathematical Sociology 1(1): 119–132.
Typical behaviour of this model is seen in the video below.

title: 3.8 Simple voter model
text:
This model is an implementation of a simple voter model. In the simple voter model there is no emergence of new classes. Eventually (where eventually might be a very long time) all but one class will disappear from the system.





Typical behaviour of this model is seen in the video below.

title: 3.1 Local averaging
text:
A model illustrating the smoothing or diffusion effect produced by iterative local averaging.





Typical behaviour of this model is seen in the video below.

title: 3.2 Vicsek’s model of galaxy formation
text:
This is an implementation of the model described in
Vicsek T and AS Szalay. 1987. Fractal distribution of galaxies modeled by a cellular-automaton-type stochastic process. Phys. Rev. Lett. 58, 2818-21.





Typical behaviour of this model is seen in the video below.

title: 3.7 Simple rock – scissors – paper IPS model
text:
This model is an implementation of a rock – scissors – paper succession model.
In this system, as in the game of rock-scissors-paper each of the three classes beats one other in a cycle. This leads to waves of succession across the space as each class ‘flees’ from the class that beats it and ‘invades’ the class that it beats.





Typical behaviour of this model is seen in the video below.
crumbs: 3.7 Simple rock – scissors – paper IPS model

title: 3.4 Basic two dimensional contact process
text:
This is an implementation of a basic contact process in two dimensions. The contact process is one of the simplest possible interacting particle systems. It is discussed in some detail in
Durrett R and SA Levin. 1994. Stochastic spatial models: a user’s guide to ecological applications. Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London. Series B 343, 329-350.





Typical behaviour of this model is seen in the video below.

title: 4.5 Foraging in a heterogeneous environment
text:
This model demonstrates how the distribution of resource availability in an environment can strongly influence the characteristics of movement motivated by exploitation of the resource. This model is loosely based on that described in
Boyer D, G Ramos-Fernández, O Miramontes, JL Mateos, G Cocho, H Larralde, H Ramos and F Rojas. 2006. Scale-free foraging by primates emerges from their interaction with a complex environment. Proceedings of the Royal Society. Series B 273 1743-50.





Typical behaviour of this model is seen in the video below.

title: 4.6 The effect of environmental change on movement
text: This model shows how a changing environment can drive the characteristics of observed movement.
crumbs: 4.6 The effect of environmental change on movement

title: 4.3 Simon’s satisficing forager model on a lattice
text:
This is a loose implementation of the model of resource search discussed in
Simon HA. 1956. Rational choice and the structure of the environment. Psychological Review 63 129-38.
The model demonstrates the importance of relative direct movement for search efficiency, and the importance of vision, in an environment where resources are relatively rare.





Typical behaviour of this model is seen in the video below.
crumbs: 4.3 Simon’s satisficing forager model on a lattice

title: 4.1 Random walks
text:
This model implements a number of variations on the random walk including the lattice-based walk, the simple random walk, walks with different distributions of step lengths, and correlated (direction) random walks.





Typical behaviour of this model is seen in the video below.

title: Spatial Simulation
text:
Across the sciences, simulation models are an important way to study systems inaccessible to experimental and observational methods, and also an essential complement to those approaches. The research literature is teeming with abstract simulation models whose presentation is mathematically demanding and requires deep knowledge of quantitative and computational methods. Furthermore, simulation models designed to represent specific systems and phenomena are often complicated, and, as a result, difficult to reconstruct from their descriptions in the literature. Spatial Simulation: Exploring Pattern & Process provides a practical and accessible account of dynamic spatial modelling, equipping readers with a sound conceptual foundation in the subject, and an introduction to the wide-ranging literature.



The book is organised around the idea that a small number of spatial processes underlie the wide variety of dynamic spatial models. Its central focus on three ‘building-blocks’ of dynamic spatial models — forces of attraction and segregation, individual mobile entities, and processes of spread — guides the reader to an understanding of the basis of many of the complicated models in the research literature. The three building-block models are presented in their simplest form and are progressively elaborated and related to real world process that can be represented using them. Introductory chapters cover essential background topics, particularly the relationships between pattern, process and spatiotemporal scale. Additional chapters consider how time and space can be represented in more complicated models, and methods for the analysis and evaluation of models. Finally, the three building-block models are woven together in a more elaborate example to show how a complicated model can be assembled from relatively simple components.

title: Spatial Simulation
text:
Across the sciences, simulation models are an important way to study systems inaccessible to experimental and observational methods, and also an essential complement to those approaches. The research literature is teeming with abstract simulation models whose presentation is mathematically demanding and requires deep knowledge of quantitative and computational methods. Furthermore, simulation models designed to represent specific systems and phenomena are often complicated, and, as a result, difficult to reconstruct from their descriptions in the literature. Spatial Simulation: Exploring Pattern & Process provides a practical and accessible account of dynamic spatial modelling, equipping readers with a sound conceptual foundation in the subject, and an introduction to the wide-ranging literature.



The book is organised around the idea that a small number of spatial processes underlie the wide variety of dynamic spatial models. Its central focus on three ‘building-blocks’ of dynamic spatial models — forces of attraction and segregation, individual mobile entities, and processes of spread — guides the reader to an understanding of the basis of many of the complicated models in the research literature. The three building-block models are presented in their simplest form and are progressively elaborated and related to real world process that can be represented using them. Introductory chapters cover essential background topics, particularly the relationships between pattern, process and spatiotemporal scale. Additional chapters consider how time and space can be represented in more complicated models, and methods for the analysis and evaluation of models. Finally, the three building-block models are woven together in a more elaborate example to show how a complicated model can be assembled from relatively simple components.

title: Spatial Simulation
text:
The model ‘zoo’
To aid understanding, more than 50 specific models described in the book are available on this site for exploration in the freely available NetLogo platform. You can access the models with (very) brief accompanying descriptions from the Model ‘zoo’ drop-down menu, organized by chapters.
More recently updated versions of the models are available on this github repository, which is kept current with recent releases of NetLogo. You can get all the models in this zipped archive.

title: Spatial Simulation
text:
The aim of the book
This book encourages readers to develop intuition for the abstract types of model that are likely to be appropriate for application in any specific context. Spatial Simulation: Exploring Pattern & Process will be of interest to undergraduate and graduate students taking courses in environmental, social, ecological and geographical disciplines. Researchers and professionals who require a non-specialist introduction will also find this book an invaluable guide to dynamic spatial simulation.
The book is published by Wiley and is available now!

title: Spatial simulations: what? why? how?
text:
In this chapter we discuss the concept of a model, why simulation models in particular have become such an important scientific tool in recent decades, and finally the particular focus of the book on spatial simulation models. Along the way we consider the game of life cellular automaton as an example of behavioural complexity (and also as a very simple dynamic model), and also simple statistical models to illustrate the strengths and weaknesses of simple abstract models.












1.1 Conway’s game of life



















1.2 Additive Galton board



















1.3 Multiplicative Galton board















No matching items

title: 1.1 Conway’s game of life
text:
A simple implementation of John Conway’s game of life cellular automaton.
See also the totalistic automata model, which allows a wide range of the cellular automata models of which life is just an example to be explored. Also of interest may be the effect on the life CA of changing how we represent time.





Typical behaviour of this model is seen in the video below.

title: 6.6 Game of life on an ‘infinite’ lattice
text: This model demonstrates how the game of life can be implemented on an ‘infinitely extensible’ lattice by only recording the locations of live cells.
crumbs: 6.6 Game of life on an 'infinite' lattice

title: 6.5 Voronoi tessellation based voter model
text:
This model demonstrates a voter model on a Voronoi tessellation. Again, the outcomes are not qualitatively different from those on a grid-based lattice.


Typical behaviour of this model is seen in the video below.

title: 6.2 Majority rule automata under different update sequencing
text: This model demonstrates how changing the sequencing of the majority rule cellular automaton update rule leads to different outcomes.
crumbs: 6.2 Majority rule automata under different update sequencing

title: 8.1 leGUME (the Grand Unified Model of Everything)
text:
Here we present a model that uses elements from all the ‘building-block’ models presented in Chapters 3, 4 and 5 to develop a more complicated and detailed model. The island coastline is formed by invasion percolation, resources are distributed according to local averaging and cluster formation, hunter-gatherers move using variations on random walk and foraging, and so on.
A detailed description of the model is available here.


In later work, we published detailed results from this model as
Perry GLW and D O’Sullivan. 2018. Identifying narrative descriptions in agent-based models representing past human-environment interactions. Journal of Archaeological Method and Theory, 25(3) 795-813.
Typical behaviour of this model is seen in the video below.
crumbs: 8.1 leGUME (the Grand Unified Model of Everything)

title: 9.1 The difficulty of inferring process from pattern
text:
This is an implementation of the model described in
Cale WG, GM Henebry and JA Yeakley. 1989. Inferring process from pattern in natural communities. BioScience 39 600-605.
which demonstrates the challenges involved in inferring processes from patterns.
crumbs: 9.1 The difficulty of inferring process from pattern

title: Model uncertainty and evaluation
text:
This chapter considers the wide range of methods available for the evaluation of models. The key idea underlying any such evaluation is to get to grips with the uncertainties inherent in any stochastic model of a spatial process – the range of variation in model outcomes, and how (if at all) we can make useful inferences from models about real-world processes.












7.1 Ruckelshaus model of dispersal















No matching items

title: 7.1 Ruckelshaus model of dispersal
text:
This is an implementation of the model of the relationship between dispersal and fragmentation described in
Ruckelshaus M, C Hartway and PM Kareiva. 1997. Assessing the data requirements of spatially explicit dispersal models. Conservation Biology 11 1298-1306.

title: In conclusion
text:
We close with (one more!) model and some final thoughts on the usefulness of spatial simulation models and the model-building process.












9.1 The difficulty of inferring process from pattern















No matching items

title: Weaving it all together
text:
In this chapter we present a model that combines elements from many of the models throughout the book.












8.1 leGUME (the Grand Unified Model of Everything)















No matching items

title: 6.3 Implementing an event queue
text: This model demonstrates how an event-based model of time can lead to much faster operation of functionally identical models.

title: 6.1 Game of life with different update timings
text: This model demonstrates how changing the sequencing of the game of life update rule leads to different outcomes.
crumbs: 6.1 Game of life with different update timings

title: 6.4 Voter model on a hexagonal lattice
text:
This model demonstrates a voter model on a hexagonal lattice. The outcomes are not qualitatively different from those on a grid-based lattice.


Typical behaviour of this model is seen in the video below.
crumbs: 6.4 Voter model on a hexagonal lattice

title: Representing time and space
text:
In earlier chapters we have not considered how apparently simple choices about how to represent time (synchronously, asynchronously, or event-based?) and space (as a grid, as a network, as points, as polygons?) may affect both model outcomes and also affect the realism of the resulting models. In this chapter various aspects of these choices are given due consideration.












6.1 Game of life with different update timings



















6.2 Majority rule automata under different update sequencing



















6.3 Implementing an event queue



















6.4 Voter model on a hexagonal lattice



















6.5 Voronoi tessellation based voter model



















6.6 Game of life on an ‘infinite’ lattice















No matching items

title: 1.3 Multiplicative Galton board
text: This model simulates a multiplicative Galton board, which demonstrates the central limit theorem of statistics as it relates to a multiplicative process.

title: 1.2 Additive Galton board
text: This model simulates a Galton board, which demonstrates both the central limit theorem of statistics as it relates to additive processes, and also the expected displacement associated with a 1-D random walk.

title: About the authors
text:
David O’Sullivan is Geospatial Stuff and an Honorary Professor in the School of Environment at the University of Auckland.
George Perry is Professor of Environmental Science at the University of Auckland.

title: 4.2 The correlation length effect in random walks
text: This model demonstrates how a correlated random walk, when consecutive steps are aggregated, reverts to a simple random walk without correlation but with a longer mean step length. This effect means that correlated random walks are ultimately diffusive (not super-diffusive) like simple random walks.
crumbs: 4.2 The correlation length effect in random walks

title: 4.7 Flocking
text:
A flocking model loosely based on ideas in
Czirók A and T Vicsek. 2000. Collective behavior of interacting self-propelled particles. Physica A: Statistical Mechanics and its Applications 281 17–29.
Grégoire G, H Chaté H and Y Tu. 2003. Moving and staying together without a leader. Physica D: Nonlinear Phenomena 181 157–70.
Vicsek T, A Czirók, E Ben-Jacob, I Cohen and O Sochet. 1995. Novel type of phase transition in a system of self-driven particles. Physical Review Letters 75 1226–29.
This model also includes various different implementations of the idea of ‘flock-mates’ which demonstrate the importance of basic spatial properties (in this case proximity or ‘neighbourhood’) in many spatial models.





Typical behaviour of this model is seen in the video below.

title: 4.4 Area searched by a ‘Simon forager’
text: Results from this model are used in figure 4.12 to demonstrate the relationship between movement tortuosity and search efficiency.

title: Random walks and mobile entities
text:
Random walks are one of the most basic stochastic processes, and furthermore provide an obvious starting point for models of mobile entities. A wide range of variations on the basic random walk idea are presented, followed by examples where walkers interact with an environment, often by searching for resources. When many mobile entities interact with one another, an interest variation is models of flocking behaviour.












4.1 Random walks



















4.2 The correlation length effect in random walks



















4.3 Simon’s satisficing forager model on a lattice



















4.4 Area searched by a ‘Simon forager’



















4.5 Foraging in a heterogeneous environment



















4.6 The effect of environmental change on movement



















4.7 Flocking















No matching items

title: 3.5 Competing contact processes
text:
This is an implementation of competing contact processes in two dimensions, including an option for one of the processes to spread over long distances. Models of this kind are discussed in
Durrett R and SA Levin. 1994. Stochastic spatial models: a user’s guide to ecological applications. Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London. Series B 343, 329-350.





Typical behaviour of this model is seen in the video below.

title: 3.6 Grass – bush – trees IPS succession model
text:
This model is an implementation of the simple grass – bush – trees model of
Durrett R and G Swindle. 1991. Are there bushes in a forest? Stochastic Processes and their Applications 37 19–31.





Typical behaviour of this model is seen in the video below.
crumbs: 3.6 Grass – bush – trees IPS succession model

title: 3.3 Totalistic automata
text:
This model allows you to explore the behaviour of a wide variety of possible totalistic automata, i.e., cellular automata whose rules are based only on the total number of cells in each neighbourhood in each of the two allowed states. The Life CA is the best known example in this class.





Typical behaviour of this model is seen in the video below. I say typical, but really there is a such a range of behaviour it would be more accurate to describe this as a typical ‘life-like’ totalistic, but the patterns it produces are all its own.

title: Aggregation and segregation
text:
In this chapter a variety of models that produce aggregated patterns are considered. The common thread is that a simple process operating locally scales up in each case to produce clustered aggregate outcomes that are often intricately structured. Processes considered include local-averaging, various cellular automata processes, contact processes, and succession models. The well-known Schelling model of residential segregation provides another example. To some extent all of these are instances of an underlying reaction-diffusion process. An alternative to these bottom-up models, is a top-down subdivision or Voronoi process.












3.1 Local averaging



















3.2 Vicsek’s model of galaxy formation



















3.3 Totalistic automata



















3.4 Basic two dimensional contact process



















3.5 Competing contact processes



















3.6 Grass – bush – trees IPS succession model



















3.7 Simple rock – scissors – paper IPS model



















3.8 Simple voter model



















3.9 Voter model with dispersal and mutation



















3.10 The Schelling model of segregation

3.13 Centroidal Voronoi tessellation



















3.14 Spots and stripes: a discrete reaction-diffusion model



















3.15 Nowak and May’s spatial prisoners’ dilemma



















3.16 Evolutionary spatial prisoners’ dilemma















No matching items

title: 3.9 Voter model with dispersal and mutation
text:
This model implements a simple voter model with two non-local processes.
One allows succession at a distance, while the other (mutation) allows the appearance of completely new states in the lattice. It is generally difficult for new states to establish themselves in the system, but over time as the original states diminish it becomes impossible to tell initial and new states apart.





Typical behaviour of this model is seen in the video below.
crumbs: 3.9 Voter model with dispersal and mutation

title: 3.11 Schelling model implemented as an IPS
text:
This model demonstrates how the Schelling model can be implemented as an interacting particle system exclusion process.





Typical behaviour of this model is seen in the video below.
crumbs: 3.11 Schelling model implemented as an IPS

title: 3.12 Iterative binary subdivision
text:
This model implements an interative subdivision process to construct a binary space partition which might be used to initialise neutral landscapes.





Typical behaviour of this model is seen in the video below.

title: 3.15 Nowak and May’s spatial prisoners’ dilemma
text:
This model is an implementation of the one described in
Nowak MA and RM May. 1992. Evolutionary games and spatial chaos. Nature 359 826-29.





Typical behaviour of this model is seen in the video below.
crumbs: 3.15 Nowak and May’s spatial prisoners’ dilemma

title: 2.7 The double Thomas point process
text: This model demonstrates a double Thomas point process where consecutive ‘generations’ of point events originate from the location of ‘parent’ events. Although the process is not intended as a dynamic model, it clearly shows how we can progress from a static to a dynamic model, similar to that of Flügge et al.

title: 2.4 The inhomogeneous point process
text: This is model demonstrates an inhomogeneous Poisson point process in which the probability of a point event occurring varies from place to place across the area of interest.

title: 2.1 Scaling a pattern
text: This model demonstrates some of the challenges involved in rescaling patterns. To run this model you will also need this NetLogo source file and this text file.

title: 2.3 Complete spatial randomness for a point pattern
text: This model simulates the independent random process or complete spatial randomness for a spatial point process.
crumbs: 2.3 Complete spatial randomness for a point pattern

title: 5.2 The ant in the labyrinth
text:
This is an implementation of the classic ant in the labyrinth problem, discussed in
de Gennes PG. 1976. La percolation: un concept unificateur. La Recerche 7 72–82.


Typical behaviour of this model is seen in the video below.

title: 5.1 Site percolation
text:
This model demonstrates site percolation and displays the largest and spanning clusters (if the latter exists).
The mathematics of percolation is fundamental to all of the models discussed in this chapter, and can also inform understanding of many phenomenon in the real world such as fire spread, dispersal, and epidemic processes.

title: 5.19 The ‘sand-pile’ forest fire model
text:
This model is an implementation of a simple forest fire model with a primary focus on the size distribution of the fires that are produced. It is based on the model described in
Bak P and K Chen. 1990 A forest-fire model and some thoughts on turbulence. Physics Letters A 147 297–300.


Typical behaviour of this model is seen in the video below.

title: 5.4 The percolation backbone
text:
This model demonstrates the identification of the backbone of a spanning cluster in site percolation. See
Herrmann HJ, DC Hong DC and HE Stanley. 1984. Backbone and elastic backbone of percolation clusters obtained by the new method of ‘burning’. Journal of Physics A: Mathematical and General 17 L261–L266.

title: 5.20 Forest fire model with age-related flammability
text:
This model is a forest fire model where the flammability of sites changes with the time elapsed since the site last burned. The focus of this model is on the relationship between the ‘flammability function’ and the resulting distribution of fire sizes, and on how ‘memory’ in the landscapes contributes to the overall patterns that result.
This model draws on ideas in


Kitzberger T, E Araoz, JN Gowda, M Mermoz and J Morales. 2012. Decreases in fire spread probability with forest age promotes alternative community states, reduced resilience to climate variability and large fire regime shifts. Ecosystems 15 97-112.
Peterson GD. 2002. Contagious disturbance, ecological memory, and the emergence of landscape pattern. Ecosystems 5 329-338.
Typical behaviour of this model is seen in the video below.
crumbs: 5.20 Forest fire model with age-related flammability

title: Percolation and growth
text:
The models in this chapter provide a basis for both models of landscape pattern, and for diffusive spread through such landscapes. The underlying basis of all these models is percolation which partitions a space into either occupied or unoccupied sites either all at once, or sequentially according to some simple rule, to yield a wide variety of models of growth processes.












5.1 Site percolation



















5.2 The ant in the labyrinth



















5.3 Site percolation forest fire model



















5.4 The percolation backbone



















5.5 Invasion percolation



















5.6 Invasion percolation drainage basin model



















5.7 Simple Eden growth model



















5.8 Inverted Eden process



















5.9 The Eden tree



















5.10 Eden ‘tip’ model



















5.11 Williams-Bjerknes Eden growth model for abnormal cells



















5.12 Eden growth a linear invasion front

title: 5.12 Eden growth a linear invasion front
text:
This model draws on ideas discussed in
Edwards SF and DR Wilkinson. 1982. The surface statistics of a granular aggregate. Proceedings of the Royal Society of London. Series A 381(1780) 17-31.
and allows you to explore the rate of progress made by an Eden invasion process advancing along a linear ‘front’.


Typical behaviour of this model is seen in the video below.
crumbs: 5.12 Eden growth a linear invasion front

title: 5.11 Williams-Bjerknes Eden growth model for abnormal cells
text:
This model is an implementation of the process described in
Williams T and R Bjerknes. 1972. Stochastic model for abnormal clone spread through epithelial basal layer. Nature 236 19–21.
crumbs: 5.11 Williams-Bjerknes Eden growth model for abnormal cells

title: 5.10 Eden ‘tip’ model
text:
This model is an implementation of the Eden ‘tip’ growth process described in
Sawada Y, S Ohta, M Yamazaki and H Honjo. 1982. Self-similarity and a phase-transition-like behavior of a random growing structure governed by a nonequilibrium parameter. Physics Review A 26 3557-3563.

title: 5.14 Benguigui’s Eden process based model of urban growth
text:
This model simulates a version of Benguigui’s highly abstract model of urban growth, as discussed in
Benguigui L. 1995. A new aggregation model. Application to town growth. Physica A: Statistical Mechanics and its Applications 219 13–26.
Benguigui L. 1998. Aggregation models for town growth. Philosophical Magazine Part B 77 1269–75.
crumbs: 5.14 Benguigui’s Eden process based model of urban growth

title: 5.17 Neutral landscape generation by percolation processes
text: This model implements a number of different percolation-based neutral landscapes.
crumbs: 5.17 Neutral landscape generation by percolation processes
